body:
[From Catholic Encyclopedia:](https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/04757a.htm)

> Detraction is the unjust damaging of another's good name by the revelation of some fault or crime of which that other is really guilty or at any rate is seriously believed to be guilty by the defamer. An important difference between detraction and calumny is at once apparent. The calumniator says what he knows to be false, whilst the detractor narrates what he at least honestly thinks is true. Detraction in a general sense is a mortal sin, as being a violation of the virtue not only of charity but also of justice.

Please correct this if it's wrong, but my understand is that detraction is like attacking a person verbally and saying, "they committed this kind of crime, their opinion is completely worthless" after they have worked to restore the harm done. Say a person stole some money, but paid it back and did something good to make up for it. Now they are in good faith trying to move on in their life and are working with money. It would be wrong to bring up their past fault to try to attack them (although it may be relevant for evaluating if they are a risk of theft or fraud).

Calumny is to just plain make something up and accuse someone of it when they're not, like the same scenario above but the person didn't commit a crime in the first place.

This is something to be careful of probably in speaking about politics and in other areas.

Should anything else be mentioned on the topic of detraction and calumny?

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.
